description: Overview of Linux, its history, open-source concept, advantages, and comparison with other operating systems.
Installing Linux using virtual machines or dual boot and understanding Linux desktop environments and terminal basics.
Understanding the Linux directory hierarchy, important system directories, and absolute vs relative paths.
Learning how to move between directories and explore files using basic navigation commands.
Creating, copying, moving, renaming, and deleting files and directories in Linux.
Viewing file contents using different commands and handling large text files efficiently.
Editing text files using terminal-based editors like nano and vi.
Understanding Linux file permissions, ownership, and managing access using chmod and chown.
Searching for files and patterns within files using Linux search and filtering tools.
Using manual pages and help commands along with practice and revision of beginner-level concepts.
Understanding standard input, output, and error streams and redirecting command output.
Combining multiple commands using pipes and processing text with filters like sort, awk, and sed.
Managing running processes, background and foreground jobs, and terminating processes.
Monitoring disk usage, mounting and unmounting file systems, and understanding storage devices.
Creating and managing users and groups and controlling access through permissions.
Installing, updating, and removing software packages using Linux package managers.
Understanding basic networking concepts, IP addressing, and testing network connectivity.
Creating and extracting compressed archives using tar, zip, and gzip tools.
Introduction to shell scripting, variables, input/output, and writing simple scripts.
Automating repetitive tasks using cron jobs and understanding cron syntax.
Understanding the Linux boot sequence, system initialization, and managing services with systemd.
Monitoring system performance and analyzing system logs for troubleshooting.
Using conditions, loops, and functions to write more powerful and efficient shell scripts.
Understanding inodes, file metadata, and creating hard and symbolic links.
Secure remote access and file transfer using SSH, SCP, and rsync.
Managing system security using sudo, firewalls, and basic SELinux concepts.
Installing and managing web servers like Apache or Nginx and hosting a basic website.
Introduction to database servers, basic database operations, and management using Linux.
Planning and implementing backup strategies and restoring data using Linux tools.
Diagnosing common Linux issues and applying learned skills in a practical final project.
